Title: Elevator
Slugline: INT. ELEVATOR - NIGHT
INT. ELEVATOR - NIGHT
A dimly lit elevator is filled with three people: a man, a woman, and a boy. The man is dressed in a business suit and tie, and he is holding a briefcase. The woman is dressed in a skirt and blouse, and she is holding a purse. The boy is dressed in a hoodie and jeans, and he is wearing a backpack.
The elevator comes to a sudden stop. The people in the elevator look around, startled.
The woman's face starts to turn white.
Man
(to himself)
What's wrong with the elevator?
Woman
(whispering to herself)
I'm so claustrophobic...
Man
(to himself)
You're okay. It's okay.
Boy
(to the woman)
Are you okay?
Woman
(crying)
I can't breathe...
Man
(trying to calm the woman down)
Hey, hey, take it easy. We'll be out of here in a few minutes.
Boy
(to the man)
What are we going to do?
Man
(to the boy)
I'm going to get help.
Boy
(looking around the elevator)
Should I stay here?
Man
(to the boy)
No, wait with my wife. I'll be back soon.
The man exits the elevator. The woman is still crying, but the boy is trying to console her.
Boy
(to the woman)
It'll be okay. We'll be out of here soon.
The man walks down a hallway, trying to find a way out of the building. He looks at his watch.
Man
(muttering to himself)
This is going to take a while.
Man
(to himself)
What's the best way to get out of here?
The man looks down the hallway and sees a door. He walks towards the door.
Man
(to himself)
This is the supply closet. It should have a key to the service elevator.
The man tries to open the door, but it is locked. He looks around for something to use to pick the lock.
Man
(to himself)
I can't find anything. I'll have to come back for this later.
The man looks down the hallway and sees the door to the elevator.
Man
(to himself)
There's always the elevator.
The man runs back to the elevator and starts hitting the emergency call button.
Man
(to himself)
Help me! Can anyone hear me?!
The man hears a faint beep coming from the elevator. He presses the button again.
Man
(to himself)
I know you can hear me! Someone please help me!
The man hears a noise coming from the elevator. He looks inside the elevator and sees the woman sitting on the floor, talking to the boy.
Man
(to the woman)
Are you okay?
Woman
(to the man)
Yes, I'm okay. The boy is here.
Man
(to the woman)
Thank goodness.
The woman looks at the man, startled.
Woman
(to the man)
You scared me!
Man
(to the woman)
I'm sorry. I didn't mean to scare you.
Boy
(to the man)
Is the elevator working?
Man
(to the boy)
No, it's not working. I'm trying to get help.
Boy
(to the woman)
I'm going to check the stairwell.
The boy exits the elevator and starts walking down the hallway. The man and woman follow him.
Man
(to the woman)
What's your name?
Woman
(to the man)
Jenny.
Man
(to Jenny)
I'm Tom.
Jenny
(to Tom)
It's nice to meet you.
Tom
(to Jenny)
I'm sorry you had to go through that.
Jenny
(to Tom)
It's okay. I'll be fine.
Tom
(to Jenny)
Are you still claustrophobic?
Jenny
(to Tom)
A little. But I'm okay.
Tom
(to Jenny)
Good. Do you want me to stay with you?
Jenny
(to Tom)
No, it's okay. The boy is here.
Tom
(to Jenny)
Okay. I'll be right here if you need me.
Jenny
(to Tom)
Thank you.
Tom looks at the boy, who is walking down the hallway, looking for a way out.
Tom
(to himself)
I wonder where he's going.
The man and woman watch the boy as he walks down the hallway. They both look at each other and then start walking down the hallway.
Tom
(to Jenny)
What are you doing?
Tom
(to Jenny)
Are you going to follow the boy?
Jenny
(to Tom)
Yes. I want to make sure he's okay.
Tom
(to Jenny)
Okay. But be careful.
Jenny
(to Tom)
I will.
Jenny and Tom start walking down the hallway. The boy is walking ahead, looking for a way out.
Jenny
(to the boy)
Where are you going?
Boy
(to Jenny)
I'm trying to find a way out.
Jenny

Let me help you.
Boy
(to Jenny)
I'm okay. I can find my way out.
Jenny
(to the boy)
I know. But I want to help you.
Boy
(to Jenny)
Okay.
The boy stops walking and looks at Jenny and Tom.
Boy
(to Jenny and Tom)
I know who you are.
Jenny and Tom look at the boy, startled.
Jenny
(to the boy)
And who are we?
Boy
(to Jenny and Tom)
You're my parents.
Jenny and Tom look at each other, startled.
Jenny
(to the boy)
What?
Boy
(to Jenny and Tom)
I know who you are. You're my parents.
Tom
(to the boy)
How do you know that?
Boy
(to Jenny and Tom)
I saw you at the park. When I was little, I went to the park with my parents. You were there too.
Tom
(to Jenny)
I remember that. That was a long time ago.
Jenny
(to the boy)
But how do you know it's us?
Boy
(to Jenny and Tom)
I just know.
Tom
(to Jenny)
I don't know. I don't remember seeing him before.
Jenny
(to Tom)

Tom
(to Jenny)
No. I don't. I don't even remember our son.
Jenny
(to Tom)
I remember our son.
Tom
(to Jenny)
I know you do. But I don't.
Jenny
(to Tom)
How can you forget your own son?
Tom
(to Jenny)

Boy
(to Jenny)
I don't know.

Tom

Jenny
(to Tom)
Okay.
Tom, Jenny, and the boy walk back to the elevator. They all stand together, waiting for the elevator to start moving.
Boy
(to Jenny and Tom)
Are we going to be stuck in here forever?
Jenny
(to the boy)
No. We'll be out of here soon.
Boy
(to Jenny and Tom)
How long will it take?
Jenny
(to the boy)
I don't know. It depends on how long it takes to get help.
Tom
(to the boy)
It's not going to take long. We're going to get help soon.

(to Jenny and Tom)
How do you know?

I know. Someone is coming to help us.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A dinner scene. A large dining table, with different kinds of food and expensive cutlery. The guests are well-dressed and well-rehearsed in etiquette. A senior member of the family announces a change in his will. Everybody on the table is horrified.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
Title: The Will
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A large dining table sits in the center of a lavishly decorated room. The table is set with expensive cutlery and crystal glassware. The guests are well-dressed and well-rehearsed in etiquette, seated at the table with perfect posture. Each guest has a plate of food in front of them - roast beef, green beans, and potatoes.
A silver-haired man of about fifty sits at the head of the table, his gaze fixed on the guests before him. He wears a dark suit and tie, and looks every inch the head of a successful business family.
The guests are chatting amongst themselves, but their conversation dies down as the man clears his throat. The room falls silent.
MR. HARRIS
Good evening, everyone. I know we're all anxious to get started with dinner, but I have a small matter to attend to first.
The guests exchange glances, and a few murmur amongst themselves. They seem uncomfortable, but no one speaks out.
MR. HARRIS (CONT'D)
Please, sit tight. I have an announcement to make.
The guests lean forward, listening intently.
MR. HARRIS (CONT'D)
As most of you may already know, my wife and I planned to divide our assets equally amongst all of our children. But I have decided to change my will.
The guests are shocked. A woman at the table gasps, and a few of the men look visibly upset.
MR. HARRIS (CONT'D)
I have decided to leave my entire fortune to my eldest son, Arthur.
The guests are stunned. They exchange glances, and a few of them look at Arthur in disbelief.
ARTHUR
(confused)
Dad? Why?
MR. HARRIS
(serious)
Because he is the one who deserves it.
The guests stare at Arthur, unsure of what to say.
MR. HARRIS (CONT'D)
I am proud to say that Arthur has been working hard, and has been responsible for the success of the company. He is the one who has earned our wealth, and he is the one who deserves it.
Arthur smiles faintly, looking proud and a little bit uncomfortable.
ARTHUR (CONT'D)
Thank you, Dad.
MR. HARRIS
(smiling)
Arthur, my son, I am proud of you. You have worked hard, and I want you to enjoy the fruits of your labor.
Arthur nods, looking pleased.
MR. HARRIS (CONT'D)
Now, let's eat. Enjoy your dinner.
The guests slowly begin to eat their food, but they seem distracted. They don't know what to think.
As they eat, Arthur sits up straighter, looking pleased with himself. He is relaxed, and he seems to be enjoying the attention.
The other guests, however, are not so happy. They look at Arthur with disapproval, and they exchange glances.
They don't like what Arthur has done. They don't think it's fair.
But they don't say anything.
After a few moments, they all begin to talk at once, chatting amongst themselves. They seem to be trying to forget about the announcement, and they seem to be trying to move on.
MR. HARRIS
(smiling)
I'm glad you're all feeling better.
The guests nod, and they continue to eat their food.
MR. HARRIS (CONT'D)
Arthur, I want to congratulate you on your success. You have worked hard, and I am proud of you.
Arthur smiles, looking pleased.
ARTHUR (CONT'D)
Thank you, Dad.
MR. HARRIS
(smiling)
You are welcome.
The guests continue to eat, but they seem to be thinking about what has happened. They don't know what to say, and they don't know how to react.
As they eat, Arthur keeps smiling. He looks pleased with himself, and he seems to be enjoying the attention.
But the other guests are not so happy. They don't like what has happened, and they don't think it's fair.
But they don't say anything.
After a few moments, the dinner ends, and the guests all stand up, ready to leave.
Mr. Harris stands up, looking pleased with himself.
MR. HARRIS
Thank you all for coming. I hope you enjoyed your dinner.
The guests nod, and they begin to leave.
MR. HARRIS (CONT'D)
And Arthur, thank you for your hard work. You have earned our respect, and you have earned our admiration.
Arthur nods, looking pleased with himself.
ARTHUR (CONT'D)
Thank you. I am proud to be your son.
The guests leave the room, and Mr. Harris and Arthur are left alone.
MR. HARRIS
(smiling)
I am proud to be your father.
Arthur smiles, looking pleased with himself.
ARTHUR (CONT'D)
Thank you. I love you.
Mr. Harris smiles, looking pleased.
MR. HARRIS
(smiling)
I love you too. Now, let's go to bed.
The two men leave the room together, and the screen fades to black.
THE END.</s>

[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.

INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The front door slams open, and a man in his early thirties storms into the living room. He paces back and forth, his hands gripping his hair. He is frantic, upset, and confused.
He stops and faces the hallway, where his wife is standing, her eyes glistening with tears.
HUSBAND
(yelling)
You can't do this to me! You can't leave me!
WIFE
(sobbing)
I can't live like this anymore. I can't take it anymore!
The man storms towards his wife, but she manages to get away, running into the kitchen.
She looks into the fridge, but there's nothing there. Frustrated, she slams the door shut.
She walks out of the kitchen and into the living room, where her husband is sitting on the couch, his head in his hands.
WIFE
(whispering)
Please, just talk to me.
The man looks up at her, and his expression is one of disappointment.
HUSBAND
(sighing)
I can't do this. I can't keep pretending everything is alright.
WIFE
(crying)
I know. But please, just talk to me. Please, you have to tell me why.
The man gets up from the couch and walks towards his wife, taking her by the hand.
HUSBAND
(sighing)
I don't know what to say.
He leads her to the couch and sits down, pulling her into his lap.
He takes a deep breath and looks into her eyes.
HUSBAND
(sobbing)
I have someone else.
The wife's eyes widen in shock.
WIFE
(whispering)
Who?
The man hesitates for a moment before answering.
HUSBAND
(tearfully)
No one you know.
He takes a deep breath and continues.
HUSBAND
I met her at the office. She's been working with me for a few months now. We've been seeing each other for a while.
The wife is silent, her eyes filled with tears.
WIFE

How long?
HUSBAND
(sighing)
For a few months now.
WIFE
(whispering)
Who is she?
The man hesitates for a moment, unsure of whether to tell his wife the truth.
HUSBAND
(sighing)
She's a friend from work.
WIFE

Was?
HUSBAND

No, she's still a friend.
WIFE
(whispering)
Then why are we here?
HUSBAND
(sobbing)
Because I can't keep pretending everything is okay.
The wife looks up at her husband, her eyes filled with tears.
WIFE
(whispering)
Why did you do this?
HUSBAND
(sobbing)
I don't know. I'm sorry.
WIFE

Sorry isn't enough.
The man looks up at his wife, and his expression is one of regret.
HUSBAND
I know. But please, just give me another chance.
The wife looks into her husband's eyes, and she can see the regret and the pain.
She gets up from the couch and walks towards the door.
WIFE
(sobbing)
I can't do this anymore.
She opens the door and walks out, leaving her husband behind.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A person packs her belongings into card boxes because she plans to move into a new apartment. She finds a photo of her and her best friend. A moment of happiness on her face is quickly substituted for a sad, nostalgic smile.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
Title: A New Chapter
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A woman in her late twenties, JESSICA, sits on her couch surrounded by card boxes filled with her belongings. She holds a photo of her and her best friend, KAREN, in her hands. Jessica smiles as she looks at the picture. Her smile slowly fades as she replaces it with a sad smile. She puts the photo back into a box and starts to pack other items.
INT. HOUSE - DAY
Jessica looks at her alarm clock, it's 6 a.m. She wakes up slowly and stretches her body. Jessica gets out of her bed and walks to the bathroom to take a shower. She looks at her reflection in the mirror and remembers the day when she was 21. She was ready to start a new chapter in her life.
Jessica moves out of her parents' house and into a small apartment in the city. She didn't have much but she was happy because she was finally living on her own. She had a job at a marketing agency and was making good money. She was finally independent and living the life she always wanted.
Jessica looks at her reflection again and tries to remember the last time she had felt this happy. She starts to pack her things and walks out of the bathroom. She feels a little nostalgic but she knows she has to move on.
INT. KITCHEN - DAY
Jessica walks into her kitchen and starts to make breakfast. She looks around the room and thinks about how much she's going to miss this place. She had lived here for five years and it was her first home as an adult.
Jessica takes a bite of her toast and thinks about her best friend, Karen. She and Karen had met during their first day at university. They had bonded over their love for fashion and had been best friends since then. Jessica knew she was going to miss Karen but she didn't expect to feel this way.
INT. LIVING ROOM - DAY
Jessica walks into the living room and starts to pack her belongings. She sees a box full of old photos and stops for a moment. She picks up a photo of her and Karen and smiles. She remembers the day when they had taken the photo.
They were on a road trip through the United States. They had visited 10 different states and had taken a photo in every one of them. They had visited famous landmarks such as the Grand Canyon, Yellowstone National Park, and the Statue of Liberty. They had made so many memories and had so much fun.
Jessica puts the photo back into the box and continues packing. She knows she has to move on but she can't help but feel nostalgic. She looks around the room and thinks about the good times she had here. She thinks about the parties she had thrown, the friends she had made, and the memories she had made.
Jessica walks to her bedroom and starts to pack her belongings. She looks at her bed and remembers the day when she had moved in. She had been so excited to start her new life. She had bought new furniture and had decorated her room to match her personality.
Jessica looks at her bed again and thinks about the nights she had spent here. She thinks about the nights when she had stayed up late, reading a book or watching a movie. She thinks about the nights when she had cried because she was lonely or sad. She thinks about the nights when she had laughed because she had made new friends or had a good time.
Jessica picks up a picture of her and Karen and smiles. She walks to her closet and starts to pack her clothes. She thinks about the day when she had met Karen and remembers the day when they had clicked. She remembers the first time they had hung out and the day when they had become best friends.
Jessica remembers the day when she had met Karen's family and the day when they had introduced her to their friends. She remembers the day when they had gone on their first road trip and the day when they had visited Yellowstone National Park. She remembers the day when they had started their own business and the day when they had had their first customer.
Jessica smiles as she remembers all the good times she had with Karen. She starts to pack her belongings and thinks about the future. She doesn't know what the future holds but she knows she wants to be happy. She knows she wants to move on and start a new chapter in her life.
Jessica walks to her bathroom and starts to pack her things. She thinks about the day when she had bought her first apartment and the day when she had moved in. She remembers the day when she had started her first job and the day when she had met her current boyfriend.
Jessica remembers how happy she had been in the beginning and how her happiness had slowly faded away. She remembers how she had started to feel lonely and how she had started to feel like she was in a rut. She remembers how she had started to feel like she was in a relationship for the wrong reasons and how she had started to feel like she was not in love.
Jessica walks to her bedroom and starts to pack her belongings. She thinks about the past and wonders if she should have done things differently. She wonders if she should have stayed with her boyfriend or if she should have tried to find a new job. She wonders if she should have started a new business with Karen or if she should have continued to work for the marketing agency.
Jessica walks to her kitchen and starts to pack her belongings. She thinks about her current apartment and wonders if she should have rented a different place. She knows she's going to miss the apartment she lived in for so long but she knows she has to move on.
Jessica thinks about the future and wonders what it holds. She thinks about the new place she's going to live in and the new people she's going to meet. She thinks about the new job she's going to have and the new friends she's going to make.
Jessica walks to her living room and starts to pack her belongings. She thinks about the new chapter in her life and wonders what it will be like. She knows she's going to miss this place but she knows she has to move on. She knows she has to be happy and start a new chapter in her life.

Jessica drives for a long time and thinks about the new chapter in her life. She thinks about the new place she's going to live in and the new people she's going to meet. She thinks about the new job she's going to have and the new friends she's going to make.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A woman is swimming in a pool when suddenly a man in a wet suit attacks her and pulls her down. She is fighting for her life, but the man manages to overpower her completely.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
Title: Dark Water
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A woman named Sarah is swimming in a pool late at night. She wears a dark wet suit and her long, dark hair is pulled back into a ponytail. She closes her eyes and takes a deep breath, letting her body relax in the water. She opens her eyes and looks around the pool, taking in the surroundings. The pool is lit by yellow poolside lights and the night sky is visible through the glass doors leading to the house. Sarah begins to swim laps in the pool, her body gracefully cutting through the water.
Suddenly, the serene scene is interrupted by a splash, and Sarah turns to see a man in a dark wet suit, wearing a mask and carrying a spear gun, emerging from under the water behind her. She screams and attempts to escape the pool, but the man catches her by the leg and pulls her under water. Sarah fights to free herself, but the man is too strong and manages to pull off her mask.
Sarah struggles, but the man is relentless. He pins her down and holds her under water, preventing her from resurfacing for air. She tries to kick him off, but he wraps his arms around her and holds her down, making it impossible for her to move. She begins to panic, her air supply cut off. She tries to hold her breath, but the water is filling her lungs and she can't keep it in. She tries to call for help, but the water in her lungs makes it impossible to speak. The man continues to hold her down, his grip tightening around her.
Sarah's eyes begin to water, and she can feel the water filling her lungs. She is desperate for air, but she can't seem to get it. She looks up at the man, trying to plead with him, but her eyes are watering so much that she can't see straight. She looks up at the water above her, trying to find a way to breathe, but the man is too strong and holds her down.
Sarah's body begins to ache as she struggles to breathe. She feels her muscles begin to cramp and her vision fades. She looks up and sees the man's face, but all she can make out is his dark eyes. She begins to lose consciousness and her body goes limp.
The man releases her leg and swims to the surface, dragging Sarah's limp body with him. He kicks her body to the poolside and pulls her out of the water. He removes her wet suit and begins to search her body. He finds a knife in her wet suit pocket and takes it from her. He then removes her mask and takes it, as well.
The man looks at Sarah's unconscious body and then back at the knife. He smiles and places the knife in her hand. He then removes the spear gun from her wet suit pocket and takes it. He looks back at Sarah and then begins to walk away.
Sarah's body convulses as she begins to regain consciousness. She coughs up water and begins to breathe again. She looks around, trying to focus on her surroundings, but her vision is blurry. She sees the man walking away and tries to call for him, but her voice is hoarse and she can barely speak. She looks at her hand and sees the knife. She remembers the man putting it there and begins to panic. She tries to get up, but her legs are too weak. She falls back down and looks around for a way out.
She hears footsteps approaching and looks up, trying to see who it is. She sees the man coming back towards her and begins to panic even more. She tries to get up and run, but it's too late. The man grabs her by the ankles and drags her to the edge of the pool.
Sarah screams as the man pulls her over the edge and throws her into the water. She hits the water hard and begins to sink. She reaches up, trying to grab onto something, anything, but there's nothing there. She feels herself slipping away and begins to panic. She kicks her legs, trying to swim, but her legs won't move. She looks up and sees the man standing over her, watching her die.
Sarah closes her eyes and gives up. She feels her body give way as she slips into darkness.
Suddenly, Sarah wakes up. She looks around and sees that she's in a small, dimly lit room. She sits up and looks around, trying to get her bearings. She feels a sharp pain in her side and reaches down to touch it. She feels the cold, wet material of her wet suit and remembers what happened. She begins to cry, overwhelmed by the memories of the attack.
Sarah feels a hand on her shoulder and turns around to see the man standing in front of her. He looks down at her and smiles.
"You're alive," he says. "I was worried you weren't going to make it."
Sarah looks at him, confused. "What? What are you talking about?"
"You're alive, aren't you?" the man says. "You're not dead, are you?"
Sarah looks at him, her confusion growing. "I don't understand. What are you talking about?"

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A helicopter is hovering above a snowy mountain top where some hikers got lost.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.

Title: Lost in the Mountains
Slugline: EXT. MOUNTAIN TOP - DAY
We see a helicopter hovering above a snowy mountain top. The helicopter lands and the door opens. A man dressed in military fatigues steps out.
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
Two men are sitting in front of a fireplace. One of them, the older one, is speaking.
OLDER MAN
(looking at the younger one)
I'm glad we have you on this mission. You're the best hiker we have.
YOUNGER MAN
(smiling)
Thanks, sir. I appreciate that.
OLDER MAN
(looking serious)
We're sending you to rescue a group of hikers. They were last seen on the mountains and have been missing for three days.
YOUNGER MAN
(looking confused)
I thought we were looking for terrorists?
OLDER MAN
(laughs)
You know what? They might be terrorists or just lost. Our mission is to find them and bring them back.
YOUNGER MAN
(looking determined)
Roger that, sir.
OLDER MAN
(looking at a photo)
You remember who they are?
YOUNGER MAN
Yes, sir. It's the Davis family.
OLDER MAN
(looking at him)
You know them?
YOUNGER MAN
(shaking his head)
No, sir. I just knew their names and that they were hikers.
OLDER MAN
(looking at the photo with affection)
They're a good family. I'm sorry to ask you to find them, but I'm sure you'll do a great job.
YOUNGER MAN
(smiling)
I won't let you down, sir.
OLDER MAN
(patting him on the shoulder)
You won't.
He turns and looks at the fireplace.
OLDER MAN
You're coming with us, aren't you?
YOUNGER MAN
(looking at him)
Yes, sir.
OLDER MAN
(smiling)
That's the spirit.
He turns to the younger man.
OLDER MAN
We'll be there soon. I'll call you when we're ready.
YOUNGER MAN
(looking at him)
Yes, sir.
He turns and looks at the photo.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
I'll find them.
EXT. MOUNTAIN TOP - DAY
The helicopter lands on the mountain top. A man gets out of the helicopter and starts walking towards a group of hikers.
As he approaches the hikers, he sees that they're all frozen to death.
He looks at them with tears in his eyes.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
I'm so sorry.
He turns and walks back to the helicopter. He gets in and they take off.
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The younger man is sitting in front of the fireplace. He looks at a photo of the Davis family.
He gets up and goes to his bedroom. He opens a drawer and takes out a map.
He opens the map and spreads it on the desk. He looks at it for a while and then starts to draw.
He draws a path that leads to the mountains. He looks at the map for a while and then gets up.
He goes to the kitchen and makes some coffee.
He takes a sip of coffee and sits down at the table. He looks at the map once more.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
I'll find them.
EXT. MOUNTAIN TOP - DAY
The sun is shining and the snow is sparkling. The younger man is walking on the mountain top. He's carrying a backpack with all the supplies he needs for the mission.
He takes a moment to look around and then starts walking.
He walks for a while and then stops. He looks around and then starts walking again.
He continues walking for hours. He's getting tired, but he keeps walking.
Finally, he stops and looks at his watch.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
I'm here.
He starts walking again and soon reaches a cave. He enters the cave and looks inside.
He sees that there's a small fire burning. He approaches the fire and looks around.
He sees some cans of food and water and some blankets.
He takes a deep breath and relaxes.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
I'm safe.
EXT. MOUNTAIN TOP - DAY
The younger man wakes up. He looks around and sees that it's dark.
He gets up and looks outside. He sees that it's snowing.
He turns and looks at his watch.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
I've been here for two days.
He goes to the cave and sits down.
He takes out a can of food and starts eating.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
I'm so hungry.
He finishes eating and takes a sip of water.
He looks at his watch.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
It's time to go.
He gets up and puts on his backpack. He goes outside and starts walking.
He walks for hours and then stops.
He takes out a map and looks at it.
He sees that he's on the right path.
He continues walking and soon reaches the Davis family's campsite.
He looks around and sees that it's abandoned.
He enters the campsite and looks around.
He sees that there's a tent and a campfire.
He looks at the tent and sees that it's empty.
He looks around and sees that there's a trail leading to a cave.
He takes a deep breath and starts walking.
He walks for hours and then stops.
He looks around and sees that there's a cave entrance.
He takes a deep breath and enters the cave.
He walks for a while and then stops.
He sees a small fire burning and a man sitting next to it.
The man looks at him and stands up.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
It's him.
He walks towards the man and stops.
YOUNGER MAN

Hello, sir.
OLDER MAN
(looking at him)
What are you doing here?
YOUNGER MAN
(looking at him)
I'm here to find you.
The older man looks at him and then at the fire.
OLDER MAN
(to himself)
You're right.
He turns to the younger man.
OLDER MAN

I'm sorry. I didn't expect you to find me so soon.
YOUNGER MAN

I'm glad I found you.
OLDER MAN
(to himself)
That's good.
He turns to the younger man.

(to himself)

I'm sorry for your loss.

Not his.

We're going home.
OLDER MAN

Yes, we are.

The helicopter lands on the mountain top. The younger man gets out of the helicopter and is greeted by the older man.
They shake hands and the older man looks at him.
OLDER MAN
(to himself)
That's good.
He turns to the younger man.
OLDER MAN
(to the younger man)
We need to go back.
YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)
Yes, I know.

He looks at the older man and then at the mountain top.
He turns to the older man.
YOUNGER MAN

OLDER MAN
(to himself)

He turns to the younger man.
OLDER MAN

YOUNGER MAN
(to himself)

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A trial scene. The setting is a courtroom. The defense attorney is cross-examining the witness. The scene is emotional because the attorney manages to get the truth from the witness that exonerates her client.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
Title: The Truth Shall Set You Free
FADE IN:
INT. COURTHOUSE - DAY
The courtroom is abuzz with the arrival of the most high-profile case in the state. Every inch of the gallery is filled with onlookers, cameras are flashing, and reporters are scrambling to get their stories out.
The bailiff stands at the courtroom door, checking everyone who enters. She opens the door for the DISTINGUISHED GUESTS who file into the courtroom. They take their seats in the front row directly behind the counsel tables.
A young lawyer, JAMES, stands at the center of the courtroom, waiting in front of the JUDGEâ€™s bench. He is dressed head to toe in a navy blue suit and tie. He has a confident expression and a strong posture.
The courtroom is filled as the JUDGE enters the room. He has a distinguished appearance, dressed in his black robe with a white collar. Immediately, the JUDGE takes his seat and calls for order.
JUDGE
Bailiff, letâ€™s have order in this courtroom.
At the mention of the JUDGE's name, the gallery goes silent as everyone stands at attention and the BAILIFF enters the courtroom.
The BAILIFF
All rise, your honor.
The gallery turns to face the judge, and one by one, they sit down.
The JUDGE
You may be seated.
The JUDGE looks at JAMES and nods his head in acknowledgement.
JUDGE
Mr. James, you may proceed.
JAMES walks over to the witness stand and takes his place.
JAMES
Thank you, your honor. Your honor, today we are here for the trial of Susan Thompson. Susan is charged with the murder of her husband, James Thompson.
James glances at the GUESTS as he speaks. One of the guests, a woman, is wiping away tears. She looks as though she is in shock.
Susan Thompson is on trial today. She is accused of murdering her husband James Thompson.
The witness stand is empty, as the witness has not yet arrived. JAMES turns to the gallery and looks at the GUESTS. He can see their faces. He can see their emotions. He can see their expressions.
JAMES
If anyone here knows the whereabouts of Susan Thompson, please let the bailiff know. This is an open courtroom.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: In the middle of the night a woman runs out of the house covered in blood and screams for help. Somebody broke into her house and killed her husband. All of the neighbors rush out to help her. One of them is the killer, although nobody is aware of that.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.

Title: Night of the Neighbor
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A woman named Jane runs out of a house, her hands covered in blood. She screams for help.
Jane (20s, wearing a nightgown, covered in blood): Help me! Someone broke into my house and killed my husband!
Jane stumbles out of the house, her bare feet leaving bloody footprints on the lawn. She falls to her knees, crying.
A man named Tom rushes out of his house to check on Jane.
Tom (40s, wearing pajamas, looking worried): What's wrong? Where's your husband?
Jane shakes her head.
Jane (crying): He's dead, Tom. Someone killed him!
Tom looks around, trying to see if he can find anything.
Tom: Are you sure you didn't see who did it?
Jane nods.
Jane: I didn't see anything. I was asleep and suddenly I heard a noise. When I got up to see what it was, I saw the man in our bed, dead.
Tom nods sympathetically.
Tom: I'm sorry, Jane. I'll go call the police.
Jane nods again, still crying.
Tom turns to head back inside his house, but then turns back to Jane.
Tom: Do you need me to call someone else? A friend or family member?
Jane shakes her head.
Jane: No, my sister lives in another state. I don't have anyone else.
Tom nods and heads back inside his house. He grabs his phone and dials 911.
Tom (into phone): Hello, we need an ambulance and the police. Jane's husband was just killed in his house.
Tom hangs up the phone and looks back at Jane.
Tom: The police should be here soon.
Jane nods and begins to wipe her tears. She stands up and looks around, taking in the scene.
Jane: What am I going to do now?
Suddenly, the man who is responsible for Jane's husband's death appears from behind the house. He looks around, trying to see if anyone is watching him.
MAN (30s, wearing a hoodie and jeans, looking guilty): What's all the commotion about?
Tom looks around, trying to see who the man is talking to.
Tom: What? Oh, just someone who broke into our neighbor's house.
The man nods.
MAN: I didn't hear anything.
Tom turns back to Jane, who is watching the man with a scared expression on her face.
Tom: Jane, do you know who that man is?
Jane shakes her head.
Jane (scared): No, I don't know him.
The man who killed Jane's husband walks away, but not before Jane sees his face. It's someone she knows, but she can't place the face.
Jane's mind begins to race as she tries to figure out who the man is and why he killed her husband.
Jane: Who was that man? I know I've seen him before, but I can't place where from...
Tom puts his hand on Jane's shoulder to comfort her.
Tom: It's okay, Jane. The police will figure it out.
Jane nods and sits down on the grass. She begins to sob again.
Tom sits down beside her.
Tom: Do you want to go inside? It'll be warmer in there.
Jane shakes her head.
Jane: No, I don't want to go inside. I want to be outside.
Tom nods and puts his arm around Jane to comfort her.
Jane (crying): I can't believe he's gone. He was only 32. He had his whole life ahead of him.
Tom nods sympathetically.
Tom: I'm sorry, Jane.
Suddenly, the police and paramedics arrive.
Tom stands up and walks over to them.
Tom: My name is Tom. My neighbor's husband was just killed in his house.
The police and paramedics begin to ask Tom questions about what happened.
Jane stands up and joins Tom. She begins to explain to the police and paramedics what happened.
Jane: My name is Jane. I was asleep when I heard a noise. I got up to see what it was and I found my husband dead in our bed.
The police and paramedics begin to ask Jane questions as well. They ask her if she saw anyone or anything that could have led to her husband's death.
Jane shakes her head.
Jane: No, I didn't see anything.
The police and paramedics continue to take statements from Jane and Tom. They ask them questions about what they saw and heard.
Jane begins to feel more comfortable with the police and paramedics. She begins to tell them about her husband and their life together.
Jane: My husband was a great man. He was kind and handsome. He was also very successful. He had a great career and was very respected in the community.
The police and paramedics nod and write down everything Jane is telling them.
Suddenly, the police and paramedics begin to ask Jane more questions about her husband and their relationship. Jane begins to think they are suspicious of her.
Jane: What do you need to know about my husband and me?
The police and paramedics look at each other, unsure of how to answer Jane.
Police Officer (30s, wearing a police uniform, looking serious): Jane, are you sure your husband was killed by someone else?
Jane looks at the police officer in surprise.
Jane: What do you mean? Of course he was killed by someone else. I didn't do it!
The police and paramedics look at each other again. They are not sure what to make of Jane's reaction.
Suddenly, the man who killed Jane's husband appears from behind the house. He looks around, trying to see if anyone is watching him.
Jane sees the man and points at him.
Jane: He's the one who did it!
The police and paramedics look at the man, who quickly runs away.
Suddenly, the man who killed Jane's husband is tackled by the police. He fights with them, trying to escape.
Jane starts to walk towards the man, but then stops.
Jane: Tom, go get my gun.
Tom looks at Jane in surprise.
Tom: What? No, Jane!
Jane looks at Tom with a determined expression on her face.
Jane: Go get my gun.
Tom looks at Jane and then runs towards the house.
Jane walks over to the man who killed her husband. She pulls out a gun and points it at him.
Jane: You're going to pay for what you did.
The man looks at Jane with a scared expression on his face.
MAN: Please, don't. I didn't mean to.
Jane looks at the man with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: What?
The man looks at Jane with a pleading expression on his face.
MAN: Please, I didn't mean to. I didn't know he was going to die.
Jane looks at the man with a puzzled expression on her face.
Jane: What do you mean?
The man looks at Jane with a scared expression on his face.
MAN: I didn't mean to. I just wanted to break into your house and steal something. I didn't know your husband was going to be home.
Jane looks at the man with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: My husband?
The man nods his head.
MAN: Yes, your husband.
Jane looks at the man with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: But why?
The man looks at Jane with a scared expression on his face.
MAN: I don't know. I didn't mean to.
Jane looks at the man with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: Why did you do it?
The man looks at Jane with a scared expression on his face.
MAN: I don't know. I just wanted to break into your house and steal something.
Jane looks at the man with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: Why?
The man looks at Jane with a scared expression on his face.
MAN: I don't know. I just wanted to break into your house and steal something.
Suddenly, Tom comes running out of the house with a gun in his hand.
Tom: Jane, no!
Jane looks at Tom with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: Tom, what are you doing?
Tom looks at Jane with a scared expression on his face.
Tom: Jane, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to.
Jane looks at Tom with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: What are you talking about?
Tom looks at Jane with a scared expression on his face.
Tom: I'm sorry, Jane. I just wanted to break into your house and steal something.
Jane looks at Tom with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: What?
Tom looks at Jane with a scared expression on his face.
Tom: I'm sorry, Jane. I didn't mean to.
Jane looks at Tom with a shocked expression on her face.
Jane: What?
Suddenly, the police and paramedics come running out of the house, guns drawn.
Police Officer: Freeze!
Tom and Jane freeze in their tracks, still looking at each other with shocked expressions on their faces.
The police and paramedics approach Tom and Jane.
Police Officer: Put down the gun, Tom.
Tom looks at the police officer with a shocked expression on his face.
Tom: What?
The police and paramedics approach Tom and Jane.

Tom looks at the police officer with a shocked expression on his face.
Tom: What?

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A man takes up dancing because his wife used to beg him to do that. After her sudden death, he decides to honor her wish. The new chapter in his life promises new love.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
Title: Stepping Out
Genre: Romantic Drama
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A man, JIM, in his late fifties, sits in front of the TV in his dark living room. He is dressed in a nightshirt and his wife's robe, which he's been wearing since she died a week ago. He picks up the remote control and turns on the TV.
INT. TV - NIGHT
Jim flips through the channels, trying to find something to watch.
Jim (V.O.)
I don't know what to do. It's been a week since Margaret died. She was my partner, my best friend, my love. How do I live without her? I've spent every day since her death staring at the TV, not really watching anything. I can't sleep. I can't eat. There's nothing in the house that I want to eat anymore. I'm going through the motions, but I'm not really living.
He turns off the TV and rests his head in his hands. He closes his eyes and feels his wife's hand on his forehead.
Jim (V.O.)
I've been going through the motions since Margaret died. It's been a week and I haven't done anything. I haven't cooked a meal, I haven't cleaned the house, I haven't even mowed the lawn. I can't sleep, I can't eat, and I can't do anything. I just sit here and I stare at the TV and I cry. Margaret's not coming back and I don't know how to live without her.
He leans forward and turns on the lamp next to him. He opens the drawer that his wife used to keep her jewelry in. He pulls out one of her bracelets and holds it close to his heart.
Jim (V.O.)
She was so beautiful and so full of life. She made me so happy. I don't know what to do without her.
He sets the bracelet on the table and lies down on the couch. He closes his eyes.
Jim (V.O.)
I don't know how to live without Margaret.
He wakes up the next morning with a start. He looks at the clock and sees that it's six o'clock. He gets up and goes to the kitchen to make coffee. He looks out the window and sees the mailman dropping the mail in the box. He opens the door and grabs the mail. He reads through the bills and the flyers and then sees a postcard from his friend, Frank. He opens it and reads the words.
"Hey Buddy,
How are you doing? I was thinking about you and I wanted to check in. I know how hard it is to lose someone you love, believe me I know. I hope you're okay. I was wondering if you'd be interested in going for a swim. It would be nice to get out of the house and get some fresh air. Anyway, let me know what you think.
Best,
Frank"
Jim smiles and sets the card on the table. He feels a tear roll down his cheek.
Jim (V.O.)
I'm not sure if I want to get out of the house. I'm not sure if I can. I don't know how to live without Margaret.
He walks to the refrigerator and opens it. He takes out a bottle of milk and pours himself a glass. He takes a sip and grimaces.
Jim (V.O.)
I don't even know what I want to eat. I don't know if I want to eat at all.
He sets the glass on the counter and walks to the living room. He picks up his wife's robe and holds it close to his face. He smells her perfume and feels her arms wrapped around him.
Jim (V.O.)
I never want to let go. I never want to let go of her. I don't know how to live without her.
He puts on the robe and sits on the couch. He takes off his shoes and puts his feet on the coffee table. He closes his eyes and rests his head on the back of the couch. He feels a tear roll down his cheek.
Jim (V.O.)
I don't know how to live without her.
He is startled by the sound of the doorbell. He gets up and goes to the door. He looks through the peephole and sees his friend, Frank, standing on the porch. He opens the door.
Frank (V.O.)
Hey Jim, how are you doing? I was thinking about you and I wanted to check in. I hope you're doing well. I know this is a hard time, but I wanted to let you know that I'm here for you.

checklist_wise_evaluation.reason: The generated screenplay does include clear scene settings, introduces the main character, and contains dialogue and actions. However, there is a repetitive nature in the dialogue, and the screenplay lacks variety in scenes and character development. It does reflect the writing prompt's theme but does not fully showcase new love or fully honor the wife's wish of taking up dancing.

The screenplay does not reach the required length of 16,000 words and does not meticulously design each character and scene. The characters and scenes are somewhat repetitive, and the secondary character, Frank, does not leave a strong impression.

While the screenplay starts with an engaging premise, it quickly becomes repetitive, which reduces engagement. The originality is also questionable as the screenplay relies heavily on repeated dialogue rather than novel plot developments.

The response does not meet all the specified requirements, such as the length of 16,000 words, the incorporation of a dancing plotline, and the development of new love. It is also missing in terms of detailed characters and scene design.
There is significant room for improvement in terms of length, character development, plot progression, and reducing repetitive dialogue. Given these factors, the screenplay is far from flawless.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A woman is walking her pet in the park. At one point, she drops the leash, and the dog finds a friend in the park. The woman makes a witty remark, which prompts a pleasant conversation between her and a handsome man. He asks for her number so that they could go on a date.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
FADE IN:
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A 30-something woman, SARAH, sits at her desk, writing in a journal by the light of a lamp. She looks up at the time, grabs her coat and exits the house.
EXT. PARK - DAY
Sarah walks through the park with her dog, BARKLEY. She notices Barkley is not focusing on her as much as he should be. She turns to see what has caught his attention and sees a man walking with his dog, ROSIE.
SARAH
(sing-song)
Oh, no, I've lost my dog.
MAN
(laughs)
Well, at least you know he's friendly.
He sees the leash on the ground and bends down to pick it up.
MAN
(extends leash)
Do you want me to hold this for you?
Sarah takes a moment to take in his appearance. He has a strong jaw, clear blue eyes, and a mop of curly brown hair. He's wearing a white t-shirt and jeans, and he's carrying a backpack. He looks like he's in his mid-30s.
SARAH
(laughs)
I'm Sarah.
His eyes light up, and he smiles.
MAN
(smiling)
Nice to meet you. I'm Ethan.
SARAH
(smiling)
Good to meet you.
She takes the leash from him and the dogs are now back to sniffing each other.
SARAH
Do you walk your dog here often?
ETHAN
Yeah. We just moved to the neighborhood, so we're still exploring all the parks.
SARAH
Oh. What do you do?
ETHAN
I teach high school history. You?
SARAH
I'm a writer.
ETHAN
Really? That's so cool.
SARAH
What do you write?
ETHAN
I'm working on a screenplay.
They share a laugh, and they both look at the dogs.
ETHAN
(smiling)
So, would you like to go out on a date sometime?
SARAH
(pauses, then laughs)
Sure.
ETHAN
Great. Can I get your number?
SARAH
Yeah.
She gives him her phone, and he enters her number.
ETHAN
I'll call you.
ETHAN
I'm Ethan.
SARAH
Sarah.
ETHAN
(grinning)
I like that.
SARAH
Why?
ETHAN
I don't know. It just does.
EXT. PARK - LATER
Ethan and Sarah watch as the dogs play together.
SARAH
(laughs)
This is so weird. They found each other all by themselves.
ETHAN
I know.
They share a smile and look at each other.
ETHAN
Well, this was nice.
SARAH
Yeah.
They share an awkward pause as they realize they don't know how to say goodbye.
ETHAN
(smiling)
Well, thanks for letting me walk your dog.
SARAH
(smiling)
No problem.
They exchange one more smile and a nod before Ethan leaves.
SARAH
(to herself)
That was fun.
She starts walking back to her house with Barkley. As she does, she hears a noise behind her and turns to see Rosie running towards her.
SARAH
(laughs)
Sorry, Rosie. You can't come with me.
She continues walking, and Rosie keeps following her. She turns around and sees that Ethan is walking towards her.
ETHAN
(smiling)
We meet again.
SARAH
(smiling)
I guess so.
ETHAN
You live pretty close by, right?
SARAH
Yeah. It's just a few blocks away.
ETHAN
I live pretty close too.
SARAH
(smiling)
Really?
ETHAN
Yes. Do you want to come over for dinner?
SARAH
(smiling)
Sure. That sounds fun.
ETHAN
Great. I'll call you later.
SARAH
(smiling)
Okay.
They share a smile, and he turns to leave.
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
Sarah enters her house and walks towards the living room. She sees a light on and turns to see her mother, LUCY, sitting on the couch.
LUCY
(surprised)
Sarah?
SARAH
(surprised)
Lucy!
LUCY
(smiling)
Hi honey.
SARAH
(smiling)
Hi.
They share a hug.
LUCY
So, how was the park?
SARAH
(smiling)
It was great.
LUCY
(smiling)
I'm glad you had a good time.
SARAH
(smiling)
Yeah.
They share a smile.
SARAH
(smiling)
So, what brings you here?
LUCY
(smiling)
I just wanted to check in on you.
SARAH
(smiling)
I'm fine, mom.
LUCY
(smiling)
I know. I just wanted to see how you were doing.
SARAH
(smiling)
I'm fine.
LUCY
(smiling)
I know. But I just wanted to see you.
SARAH
(smiling)
How's dad?
LUCY
(smiling)
He's good.
SARAH
(smiling)
I'm glad.
They share a smile.
LUCY
(smiling)
Well, I don't want to keep you.
SARAH
(smiling)
Okay.
LUCY
(smiling)
I'll see you tomorrow.
SARAH
(smiling)
Okay.
Lucy gets up and walks towards the door.
LUCY
(smiling)
Bye.
SARAH
(smiling)
Bye.
They share a smile and a kiss goodbye before Lucy leaves.
EXT. PARK - DAY
Sarah is sitting on a bench writing in her journal. She looks up and sees Ethan walking towards her with a smile on his face.
SARAH
(smiling)
Hi Ethan.
ETHAN
(smiling)
Hi Sarah.
SARAH
(smiling)
How are you?
ETHAN
(smiling)
I'm good. How are you?
SARAH
(smiling)
I'm good.
They share a smile.
ETHAN
(smiling)
So, do you want to go out on a date tonight?
SARAH
(smiling)
Sure.
ETHAN
(smiling)
Great.
They share a smile and start walking towards the park entrance.
INT. RESTAURANT - NIGHT
Ethan and Sarah sit across from each other at a table in a restaurant.
ETHAN
(looking at her)
This is nice.
SARAH
(smiling)
Yeah.
ETHAN
(smiling)
I'm glad you said yes.
SARAH
(smiling)
I'm glad you asked.
ETHAN
(smiling)
I'm a good person, Sarah.
SARAH
(smiling)
I know.
ETHAN
(smiling)
I'm going to be a good boyfriend too.
SARAH
(smiling)
I know.
ETHAN
(smiling)
I'm going to be good at making you happy.
SARAH
(smiling)
I know.
ETHAN
(smiling)
I'm going to be good at making us happy together.
SARAH
(smiling)
I know.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: Many people are attending a funeral. The police are also present at the cemetery.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
Title: In the Shadow of Death
Setting: A small town situated on the outskirts of a major city.
Slugline: EXT. CEMETERY - NIGHT
Fog slowly creeps through the air, barely visible but giving an eerie, ominous feeling. The full moon illuminates the graveyard, but the shadows remain. The silence is almost deafening.
A hand reaches up and touches the cold stone. In the distance, a dog barks.
Slugline: INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
Gary opens the door to his house and walks in. He is in his late 30s, bald, and has a heavy build. He is a police officer, and his expression is solemn.
Slugline: INT. KITCHEN - NIGHT
Gary sits down at the table, and his wife, DANA, brings him a glass of water. She is in her early 30s and has blonde hair. She is attractive but has an air of sadness about her.
Dana: Gary, you've been up all night. You need to sleep.
Gary: That's what you said last night.
Dana: I know, I know... but I'm just worried about you.
Gary: I'll be fine. I just... I need to be focused right now.
Dana: What if you don't get any answers?
Gary: I will. I have to.
Slugline: EXT. CEMETERY - NIGHT
The fog continues to grow thicker, and the temperature drops. A few more dogs bark in the distance.
Slugline: INT. KITCHEN - NIGHT
Gary gets up and goes to a drawer, pulling out a pistol.
Dana: What are you doing?
Gary: I'm going to the funeral.
Dana: But... Gary, it's so late.
Gary: I know, but I have to be there.
Dana: Be careful.
Gary nods and leaves the house.
Slugline: EXT. CEMETERY - NIGHT
Gary walks through the graveyard, and the fog is now so thick that he can barely see three feet in front of his face. The sound of barking grows louder and more frequent.
Slugline: EXT. CEMETERY - NIGHT
Gary walks up to a grave, and the sound of barking becomes very loud. He sees two dogs in the distance.
Gary: Go on. You're safe now.
Slugline: INT. POLICE STATION - DAY
A few hours have passed. Officer HARRY is at his desk, and he looks over at Officer MICHAEL, who is sitting at his desk. Harry is in his mid-40s and has dark hair and a heavy build. Michael is in his mid-30s and has blonde hair and a lean build.
Harry: You look like you've been up all night.
Michael: I have. I couldn't sleep.
Harry: Did you find anything?
Michael: Not much. One of the victims was shot and the other one was beaten to death.
Harry: With what?
Michael: A pipe.
Harry: That's a very odd choice.
Michael: Yeah. The only thing that connects them is that they were both murdered.
Harry: That's all we have for now. Let's keep looking.
Slugline: INT. KITCHEN - NIGHT
Gary sits down at the table again, and Dana brings him a cup of coffee.
Dana: You're still up?
Gary: Yeah, I can't sleep.
Dana: Do you want to talk about what happened?
Gary: There's not much to say. I looked around the house, and everything was in order.
Dana: That's good.
Gary: Yeah. I don't have a lot of leads right now.
Dana: Maybe you should take a break.
Gary: I have to keep going.
Dana: You've been working on this case for weeks. You need to rest.
Gary: I know that, but...
Harry: Gary!
Gary: What?
Harry: We need you to go to the funeral. There's a lot of people there. We need to know if anyone saw or heard anything.
Gary: I'll go.
Slugline: EXT. CEMETERY - NIGHT
Gary walks through the graveyard again, and the fog is even thicker now. He reaches the grave of the victims, and the dogs are still barking.
Gary: I know, I know. You're safe now. Go on.
Slugline: INT. POLICE STATION - DAY
Harry and Michael are sitting at their desks, and Officer DAVID walks over to them. David is in his mid-30s, has blonde hair, and is lean.
David: What's going on?
Michael: Gary found the second body.
David: That's terrible.
Harry: We're trying to figure out what happened. That's all we know right now.
Slugline: INT. KITCHEN - NIGHT
Dana is in the kitchen, and she is upset. She goes to the phone and dials a number.
Dana: Hello. This is Dana. Yes, I need to speak to my husband, Gary.
Slugline: EXT. CEMETERY - NIGHT
Gary continues to walk through the graveyard, and the fog is even thicker now. He reaches the grave of the victims, and the dogs are still barking.
Gary: I know, I know. You're safe now. Go on.
Slugline: INT. KITCHEN - NIGHT
Dana answers the phone.
Dana: Gary, what happened?
Gary: It's the same thing. I checked the house, and everything's in order.
Dana: That's good.
Gary: Yeah. I'm going back to the station. I need to get some sleep.
Dana: Be careful.
Gary: I will.
Slugline: INT. POLICE STATION - DAY
Harry and Michael are sitting at their desks again, and David is standing behind them.
David: What are we gonna do?
Harry: We're working on it.
David: What are you gonna do?
Harry: I don't know, but we'll figure something out.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A math teacher calls the parents of a gifted boy to suggest a more advanced curriculum.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.

Title: Advanced Math
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A house in a quiet suburban neighborhood. A soft, yellow glow emanates from the windows and, through the front window, we see a family sitting together at the dinner table. The father, DAVID, is sitting at the head of the table. Next to him is his wife, MARY. There are two empty seats between them. The dinner table is set for four, and there is a vase of spring blossoms in the center. The table is set with a white tablecloth, a vase of spring blossoms in the center, and fine china and silver. The family is eating a comfortable, but not extravagant meal of roast chicken and vegetables.
DAVID
David, this is your favorite dish, is it not?
MARY
Indeed, it is. I hope you're enjoying it, dear.
DAVID
I am, very much.
They smile at each other, and their eyes twinkle with affection as they share a silent moment of appreciation for their domestic comfort and the happiness of their family. The father, DAVID, has an air of quiet confidence about him, and his appearance suggests a hardworking man. He has graying hair and wears a well-tailored, dark blue suit. The mother, MARY, has a more delicate appearance, with long, dark hair and a gentle smile. She is dressed in a pale green dress that complements her dark hair and eyes.
DAVID
And you, my dear girl. How do you find your studies?
Their eldest daughter, JESSICA, looks up from her plate, and smiles at her father. She has the same dark hair as her mother and the same gentle smile. She looks to be about twelve years old, and she is dressed in a floral dress.
JESSICA
It's all right, Daddy. I don't find it too difficult, really.
DAVID
That's good. I was worried that it might be too much for you, but you seem to be handling it quite well.
JESSICA
Thank you. I like it. It's more challenging, but I like a challenge.
David smiles at her, and ruffles her hair affectionately. He looks at his wife, and smiles.

We have another one of these bright children, don't we, Mary?

Yes.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A famous composer is shown in the creative process of composing a musical masterpiece.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The camera pans through the dimly lit interior of a mansion, focusing on the wooden floorboards creaking with each step as someone walks towards an ornate door. The door opens and a man in his late 40s, dressed in a tailored suit, steps inside. He walks down a hallway towards a room at the end, flipping on a light switch as he enters. He sits down at a grand piano and begins to play.
FADE IN:
INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT
The camera pans back to show the living room, where a woman in her late 30s sits, reading a book. She is wearing a long, flowing nightgown and has a cup of tea balanced on her lap. The man, now on the piano, begins to play a romantic tune. The woman looks up from her book.
WOMAN
(to herself)
I love this man.
EXT. HOUSE - NEXT MORNING
The camera pans up to reveal a clear blue sky, showing the exterior of the house. The camera focuses on a window on the second floor, where a man in his late forties sits at a desk, staring at a blank sheet of music paper. He sighs and looks at the clock.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: Passengers on a plane start panicking when they learn that there is a serious problem with one of the engines. The flight attendants try to calm them down, but with little success. The plane starts falling and everybody starts screaming and praying.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
Title: Engine Failure
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The sound of a television plays in the background, but it's hard to hear above the screams. The screen is dark, except for the occasional flash of light. There's a sense of chaos in the air, as chaos reigns in the small, cluttered room.
In the center of the room sits a woman, her eyes wide with fear. She's huddled in a corner, her arms wrapped protectively around her legs. Her breath comes in ragged gasps, and her face is pale with panic. She's wearing a thick sweater, and her feet are bare.
To her left is a man, kneeling on the floor with his head in his hands. His shoulders are shaking, and there's a look of utter despair on his face. To his right is a small child, hugging her knees to her chest and shivering.
The sound of footsteps can be heard approaching, and everyone turns to see a woman in a uniform enter the room. She's carrying a tray of food, and she looks exhausted.
The woman in the corner looks up, her eyes wide with terror. She stares at the woman in the uniform, and then at the tray of food. Her stomach rumbles, but she can't seem to get enough air to speak.
The uniformed woman sets the tray down and kneels next to the woman in the corner. She takes her hand in her own, looking at her with concern. The woman in the corner looks up at her, her eyes clouded with fear.
The uniformed woman speaks. "It's going to be okay, Miss. You're safe now."
The woman in the corner looks at her, tears streaming down her face. She can't seem to find the words to speak.
The uniformed woman nods, and looks down at the tray. "You could use something to eat. Would that be okay?"
The woman in the corner nods, and the uniformed woman smiles. She takes a cup of tea from the tray and hands it to the woman. The woman takes it gratefully, taking a sip.
She looks at the uniformed woman, and finally speaks. "I don't know what's going on. I just...I just don't know."
The uniformed woman nods, and sets the tray down. She takes the woman's hand in her own, and looks at her. "You're safe now. You're going to be okay."
The woman nods, and a single tear rolls down her face. She looks around the room, and sees the man and the child. She looks back at the uniformed woman, and her eyes fill with tears.
The uniformed woman smiles, and stands up. She reaches for the tray, and then turns to the man and the child. "You two should eat something, as well. It's not going to be long now."
The man nods, and takes the tray. He helps the child up, and they both sit down. The man starts to cry, and the child hugs him tightly.
The uniformed woman smiles, and turns to leave. She looks back at the woman in the corner, and then walks out of the room.
The woman in the corner watches her go, her heart heavy with fear. She looks down at the cup of tea, and then takes another sip. She looks around the room, and then at the man and the child.
She looks down at her hands, and then up at the ceiling. She closes her eyes, and says a silent prayer.
The sound of footsteps can be heard approaching, and everyone looks up.
A woman with dark hair and a stern look on her face enters the room. She looks around, and then turns to the woman in the corner.
"Miss, I need you to tell me what happened."
The woman in the corner looks up at her, her eyes wide with fear. She can't seem to find the words to speak.
The woman with dark hair looks at her, and then at the uniformed woman. "Come with me, Miss. I need to ask you some questions."
The woman in the corner nods, and the uniformed woman walks over to her. She helps her up, and the woman limps out of the room.
The woman with dark hair turns to the man and the child, and gives them a stern look. "You two need to tell me what happened as well."
The man nods, and the woman with dark hair smiles. She turns to leave, and then stops. She turns back to the man and the child, and gives them a stern look.
"I need you to tell me the truth now. I won't ask again."
The man nods, and the woman with dark hair nods back. She turns to leave, and then stops again. She turns back to the woman in the corner, and gives her a stern look.
"Don't worry. You're safe now."
The woman in the corner nods, and the woman with dark hair turns to leave.
The man and the child start to speak, but they're interrupted by a loud crash. The sound of breaking glass can be heard, and everyone looks up.
The sound of footsteps can be heard approaching, and everyone looks up.
A man in a uniform enters the room, and everyone looks at him in fear. He looks around, and then turns to the woman with dark hair.
"What happened?"
The woman with dark hair looks at him, and then at the man and the child. "The engine failed. We had to land."
The man in the uniform nods, and looks at the woman in the corner. "Why didn't you call for help?"
The woman in the corner looks up at him, her eyes wide with fear. She can't seem to find the words to speak.
The man in the uniform nods, and looks at the woman with dark hair. "I need to talk to everyone separately. You two, come with me."
The man and the child follow the man in the uniform out of the room. The woman with dark hair turns to the woman in the corner, and gives her a stern look.
"I need you to tell me everything. Everything that happened."
The woman in the corner nods, and the woman with dark hair nods back. She turns to leave, and then stops.
She turns back to the woman in the corner, and gives her a stern look. "Don't worry. You're safe now."
The woman in the corner nods, and the woman with dark hair turns to leave.
The woman in the corner looks around the room, and then at her hands. She closes her eyes, and says a silent prayer.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: Five children ride their bikes in the forest when they see something extraordinary. One of them panics and wants to go back and bring his parents, but the other children act in a braver way, as if they were mature enough.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
response:
Title: The Extraordinary Encounter
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The silence in the house is broken by the sound of a creaking door. A young boy, JOE, 10, slowly opens his door and peeks out. He looks around, seeing no one. He takes a deep breath and then opens the door wider. He walks out and down the stairs, stopping for a moment at the foot of the stairs.
Joe starts for the front door, but stops as he hears a noise coming from upstairs. He hesitates for a moment before slowly starting up the stairs. He stops halfway up, looking into the darkness of the hallway.
After a few seconds, Joe continues up the stairs and into his parent's bedroom. He stops for a moment, listening to the sound of his parents' breathing. He takes a deep breath and then approaches the bed.
He stops again as he sees his parents' breathing become more rapid. He looks at them, his eyes wide with fear.
Suddenly, he starts to turn and then stops, as if he remembered something. He slowly turns back to his parents and then reaches out, touching his mother's face.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A birthday party goes wrong when the boy's father returns home drunk and aggressive.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.

Title: The Wrong Party
Slugline: INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
We hear the screams from outside. A car screeches to a halt. The front door slams open, and there's a moment of silence. Then, the sound of footsteps thumping up the stairs.
We see a six-year-old boy, JOEY, standing in the kitchen, waiting anxiously. He's wearing a big grin. His mother, MARIA, is in the living room, tidying up.
Maria hears Joey's footsteps, and she turns to look at him. She raises her eyebrows questioningly, but Joey is silent.
Maria shakes her head and returns to the kitchen. She goes to the fridge and takes out a birthday cake. Joey gasps in delight.
Maria smiles and takes a slice of cake out of the box. She puts it on a plate and moves back to the living room.
INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT
Joey follows his mother into the living room. He looks around in excitement. The room is decorated with balloons, streamers, and birthday candles.
Joey's father, BRIAN, walks into the room. He is drunk, and he trips over the balloons on his way to the couch.
Joey grins, and Maria smiles nervously.
Brian leans back on the couch, smiling. Joey jumps up and down excitedly.
"I'm sorry, buddy," Brian says. "I know I missed your birthday."
Joey shakes his head. "It's okay. I'm still happy that you're here."
Brian's smile fades as he looks at Maria. "You're still married, right?"
Maria looks at Brian, confused. "Yes, of course. What do you mean?"
"I mean, I'm sorry. I'm just drunk."
Maria doesn't respond. She just walks over to the cake and cuts a slice for Joey.
Brian watches her for a moment before standing up and walking over to the bar.
Joey watches his father with wide eyes.
INT. KITCHEN - NIGHT
Maria watches as Brian pours himself a glass of whiskey. She shakes her head and walks over to him.
"Please, Brian," she says. "Don't drink."
Brian looks at her, smiling. "I'm just celebrating my son's birthday."
"But you're drunk," Maria says.
"I'm not drunk," Brian says. "I'm just having a few drinks."
Maria nods and walks away. Brian takes a drink from his glass.
INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT
Joey is sitting on the couch, looking at his father. Brian is sitting next to him, drinking.
"Dad, why were you so late?" Joey asks.
Brian looks at Joey, and his smile fades. "I'm sorry, buddy. I got held up."
"Did you get a job?" Joey asks.
Brian looks at Joey, confused. "What do you mean?"
"You said you were going to get a job," Joey says. "Did you?"
Brian laughs. "I told you, I'm sorry I missed your birthday."
Joey's expression changes to one of disappointment.
Brian takes another drink from his glass.
Joey looks at his mother, who is standing in the corner of the room, staring at the wall.

instruction:

[Writing Prompt]: A girl writes in her diary about the boy she likes, about the teachers she dislikes, and about the fights with her sister. Suddenly, her sister enters the room, they have a big fight over something trivial, and her sister snatches the diary. She gets angry when she reads a few lines about herself in the diary.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and no shorter than 16000 words.
